DanceItOut.title: Dance It Out
DanceItOut.description: An educational and interactive game where your character needs to escape from a dance machine. You can create custom minigames with your own questions or play games created by others. You can play with keyboard keys or a dance mat if you havenâ€™t thrown yours away yet ðŸ˜œ
DanceItOut.projectGoal: To create a fun learning experience with an easy-to-use interface for creating custom minigames.
DanceItOut.targetAudience: Elementary and middle school students with basic tech literacy. Teachers, instructors, and educators.

TheProgress.title: What Are We Making?
TheProgress.problem: After deciding the game's story (a kid stuck in a dance machine), we debated about the game macanic between a multiple-choice game or a matching game.
TheProgress.solution: To decide, each of us presented our preferred macanic, and after discussion, we chose the multiple-choice game. The main reason was that itâ€™s a simple game mechanism, allowing us to focus on the finer details.

TheProgress.title: How to Make a Fun Game?
TheProgress.problem: Multiple-choice games are the most common type in educational games, so students are often less excited about them. We needed to find a way to make the game unique and create a fun experience that the learner would remember.
TheProgress.solution: We had a team discussion to identify elements that give us the â€˜wowâ€™ feeling. In the end, we decided to add an exciting story, diverse feedback, and various animations. Spoiler: the players loved it.
imgDescription: Example of positive feedback in the game

TheProgress.title: The Game Is Hard to Operate
TheProgress.problem: When players tried the initial demo, they found it difficult to understand how to operate the game. After discussing with them, we realized that the arrangement of the answers on the screen didnâ€™t match the keyboard key placements.
TheProgress.solution: To solve this, we tried various ideas like changing the order of elements and highlighting the arrow representing each answer, but eventually, we added a tutorial stage before the game starts. After this change, we saw a significant improvement in playersâ€™ understanding and enjoyment of the game.

presentProjectDescription: Screenshot from the game's intro video
DanceItOut.Summery:
I focused on the UI/UX design, coding, and creating the animations.
The key things I learned during this project were how to work as a team, prioritize tasks, and find design solutions based on user research.

DogyQuiz.title: Dogy Quiz
DogyQuiz.description: A responsive website for creating personalized quizzes about dogs. Choose a dog breed, topic, and difficulty level, and with one click, you'll get a custom quiz with 5 questions. <span class='note'>Currently, the site is disconnected from the AI model and includes 6 examples. <span/>
DogyQuiz.framework:
Final Project in Advanced Programming Course
Bachelorâ€™s Degree
DogyQuiz.projectGoal: To create a responsive website and test our ability to produce a product based on a language model in a reliable and flexible way.
DogyQuiz.targetAudience: People aged 6+ who love dogs and want to learn about them and test their knowledge in a fun and different way.

TheProgress.title: Working with AI
TheProgress.problem: Language models generate text with some randomness, making it hard to predict the output. Variations in writing style can cause issues if the format doesn't match the system's expectations.
TheProgress.solution: We conducted self-research on language models, explored structures and techniques for writing prompts, and worked with the API. This helped us refine prompts to find the right balance between stable, reliable results and creative content.

TheProgress.title: Designing the Intro Screen
TheProgress.problem: At the start of using the site, we want to explain to the user what the site is about and also allow them to choose the criteria for the quiz they want to take. We debated how to present all this information without overwhelming the user, making it suitable for both desktop and mobile.
TheProgress.solution: First, we started by designing for mobile and then expanded the design for desktop. This way, the amount of content that serves as our base would be suitable for the smallest platform, making it easier to expand rather than shorten the information. We also experimented with different layouts until we found one that allowed us to include all the information without overwhelming the user. This was achieved by integrating the information into labels and buttons.
imgDescription: Initial wireframe of the intro screen layout

DogyQuiz.Summery:
I focused on UX design, writing prompts, building the website, and handling responsiveness.
The key things I learned during this project were communicating with designers, creating responsive designs, and dealing with edge cases on the site.

GoddaGo.title: Godda Go
GoddaGo.description:
Online game designed for both computer and mobile, where you take on a unique roleâ€”God, who can only communicate with humans through lightning.

Your mission? It sounds simple but is quite the challenge: Help the main character catch a bus on time to reach an important destination.
Playtime around 10 minutes.
GoddaGo.framework: Made for the 'No Words Jam' competition
GoddaGo.projectGoal: To create a short game in less than a week without using any words.
GoddaGo.targetAudience: This game is for anyone who loves video games and wants to play something light and fun.

TheProgress.title: No Words Allowed
TheProgress.problem: The game was made for the 'No Words Jam,' where the main rule was to create a game that doesn't use any words to explain how to play or tell the story.
TheProgress.solution: To tackle this, I started by brainstorming ideas with the simplest controls possible, making them versatile so I wouldnâ€™t need to teach many mechanics. I remembered the point and click games I used to play as a kid and thought it would be cool to make a game where the click is always the same, but the effect changes based on where you click.
imgDescription: Animation of a cat bus running

TheProgress.title: Scope Creep Challenge
TheProgress.problem: The original plan for the game was pretty ambitious, with three stages and different missions and mechanics. But with a tight deadline and just two days left before submission, I realized it would be tough to fit everything in at the level I wanted.
TheProgress.solution: I broke down the work Iâ€™d done into categories (like backgrounds, animations, code, etc.) to see what was done and what could be cut. I decided to focus on the first stage Iâ€™d been working on and put all my effort into developing and upgrading it.
imgDescription: Finding the hidden character 'Bill' in the game

presentProjectDescription: The final stage - breaking a door with lightning
GoddaGo.Summery: The key things I learned during the project were how to navigate external limitations, create animations quickly, and adapt to changes on the fly.

MaccabiahOnTime.title: Maccabiah On Time
MaccabiahOnTime.description: An educational game split into two lessons. Each lesson has a group game and a class-wide final game. Throughout the game, players will talk to historical figures, solve puzzles, collect medals, and play mini-games while earning points and competing with their classmates. This project is still in progress, so itâ€™s not available yet.
MaccabiahOnTime.role:
Programmer, UX & UI Designer, and Animator
(Teamwork)
MaccabiahOnTime.projectGoal: To make the Maccabiah event exciting and engaging for kids before the 2025 event.
MaccabiahOnTime.targetAudience: This project is for teachers and students in grades 5 to 9.

TheProgress.title: How to Make a Game Fun?
TheProgress.problem: One of the toughest challenges we faced was how to take a somewhat boring topic full of historical facts and turn it into a cool product that kids would actually want to play.
TheProgress.solution: Before development, we did some research on how different games ensure that learning is fun and keeps players coming back. We decided to use an exciting story, varied interactions, and competition to make the game engaging.

TheProgress.title: Which Feedback to Take?
TheProgress.problem: During development, we gave the product to students and teachers for feedback. Sometimes the feedback was positive, and sometimes it required us to make changes. One of the challenges was balancing listening to feedback while still meeting our goals and deadlines.
TheProgress.solution: We created a document to track all the feedback and then filtered it, focusing on recurring issues or important suggestions. We looked for solutions that could address multiple problems or wouldnâ€™t cause new issues.

TheProgress.title: How Many Animations?
TheProgress.problem: One of the things we decided early on was that the product would be full of small animations. I love animations, and I believe they make a game feel 'wow' when players see them throughout the game. But creating animations takes time, and building a game from scratch makes it challenging to do everything.
TheProgress.solution: To solve this, we did a few things. For in-game animations, we built them directly in the game engine so that different elements could easily share the same animations. For the opening and closing videos, we ranked all the shots and decided where detailed animation was crucial and where sound effects or simple effects would do the job.
imgDescription: Shot from the game's opening video

presentProjectDescription: Student interface for creating a group
MaccabiahOnTime.Summery:
I focused on UX & UI design, server communication, Unity development, and animation.
The key things I learned during the project were handling edge cases, finding solutions to user-testing issues, and prioritizing tasks effectively.

Stratasys.title: Stratasys Portal
Stratasys.description: A knowledge portal that gathers all the information needed to perform the expected managerial routines at Stratasys. The portal standardizes these routines across the company, allows easy search, saving, and editing of templates to customize processes to the specific manager's needs. Thereâ€™s no link to the product as no prototype was built for this project.
Stratasys.projectGoal: To tackle a real organizational problem at Stratasys by researching it, finding a solution, and designing it.
Stratasys.targetAudience: Managers from all over the world at Stratasys.

TheProgress.title: Whatâ€™s the Organizationâ€™s Problem?
TheProgress.problem: Managers at the company need to perform various tasks and processes like onboarding new employees, giving feedback, and more. The problem was that the information needed for these processes wasnâ€™t centralized, leading to delays in what should be quick and easy tasks.
TheProgress.solution: We suggested creating an English knowledge portal, specifically for managers, built on templates and divided according to the six stages of the 'Employee Lifecycle' (Attracting, Recruitment, Onboarding, Retention, Development, and Exit).

TheProgress.title: How Will It Work?
TheProgress.problem: One challenge we faced was designing the portal to be easy to search and use, despite having so many different templates.
TheProgress.solution: Managers can search templates in a free-text search box, and popular templates will be displayed on the homepage under the 'Popular' category, saving time if theyâ€™re looking for something common. Managers can save templates they find useful under 'Saved Template' for quick access if they need them again.

presentProjectDescription: Searching for a template in the portal
Stratasys.Summery:
I focused on developing and designing the product.
The key things I learned during the project were working with a real client, adapting to client requirements, and presenting the final product.

TheWholeWorldIsOnStage.title: The Whole World Is a Stage
TheWholeWorldIsOnStage.description: A short digital course teaching the basics of public speaking. The course has two parts: one on writing presentations and the other on delivering them. The course uses videos, interactive pages, forums, and more to teach you in the most fun way possible. This product was made for Moodle, and the version you see here is a static copy, so you canâ€™t submit assignments or participate in forums.
TheWholeWorldIsOnStage.projectGoal: Creating a short MOOC (short online course) on public speaking.
TheWholeWorldIsOnStage.targetAudience: Teens, students and employees who want to improve their ability to stand in front of an audience.

TheProgress.title: Why Us?
TheProgress.problem: The topic of public speaking is huge, with countless people discussing it now and in the future. One of the first things we had to decide was what makes us unique? What can we say or show about this topic that others can't?
TheProgress.solution: The truth is, none of us are presentation geniuses, and that's where our strength lies. We built this as students, for students, and for people in similar life situations, so we know how to speak in the same language as the audience.

TheProgress.title: Development?
TheProgress.problem: My goal was to develop the entire interface in HTML. However, since it was a team project and the timeline was tight, we explored alternatives.
TheProgress.solution: We chose to explore and use the Genially platform for easier implementation. To add uniqueness, we also incorporated HTML + JS components in the model environment.

TheProgress.title: Cool Features
TheProgress.problem: One of the most important things for me was to occasionally integrate unique and interesting elements into the course, giving learners a fresh perspective and helping them grasp the material on a deeper level.
TheProgress.solution: You can see an example of this in the feature I created under the topic 'Tools and Techniques - Voice.' This feature lets the learner move the comma in a sentence like 'Everything will be okay in the end, you'll see,' and see how it completely changes how we understand and hear the sentence. This was built with JS and added above the existing content.

presentProjectDescription: Topic outline for the first part
TheWholeWorldIsOnStage.Summery:
I focused on video production and embed the product in Moodle.
The key things I learned during the project were working within a large team, managing work under tight deadlines, and finding effective ways to express myself in a collaborative environment.

ItsLogicalToSucceed.title: It's Logical to Succeed
ItsLogicalToSucceed.description: A learning module that teaches the basics of propositional logic. It takes you from the fundamentals to the point where you can solve logic puzzles on your own. The module should take about 10 to 15 minutes.
ItsLogicalToSucceed.role:
UX & UI Designer and Implements Module
(Teamwork)
ItsLogicalToSucceed.projectGoal: To develop and produce a learning module on propositional logic.
ItsLogicalToSucceed.targetAudience: Students who need to learn about propositional logic.

TheProgress.title: How to Teach in a Fun Way?
TheProgress.problem: Propositional logic can be a pretty heavy topic, and it took us some time to figure out how to make the material accessible so that anyone, even without prior knowledge, could take the module and understand it in a way thatâ€™s engaging and enjoyable.
TheProgress.solution: We tackled this with a few key elements, the main ones being design and interactivity. The moduleâ€™s design is very light and informal, aiming to ease the formal pressure of academic content. We made sure to include a variety of creative and interactive elements to make the learning experience fun, refreshing, and as intuitive as possible.

presentProjectDescription: Opening screen with an explanation of the Storyline
ItsLogicalToSucceed.Summery:
I focused on UX & UI design and creating the product in Storyline.
The key things I learned during the project were working with an instructional designer and mastering Storyline.
